item.title: News
item.description: 2024 May 2024 – Lilly won the 2024 IEEE Robotics and Automation Magazine (RAM) Outstanding Reviewer award! Apr. 2024 – David, Siqi, Tuo, and Chongxun have joined MERGe Lab as PhD students. Welcome! Apr. 2024 – Darren and Tanya have joined MERGe Lab as undergrad students. Welcome! Jan. 2024 – Annan and Lilly’s paper “Embedded air channels transform soft lattices into sensorized grippers” has been accepted to ICRA 2024! See y’all in Yokohama!

item.title: People
item.description: Current Lab Members Lillian (Lilly) Chin Principal Investigator Assistant Professor, Electrical and Computer Engineering, UT Austin Office: EER 4.820 Lab Space: EER 4.884 and 4.884A Contact form: Link Lilly received her SB, SM, and PhD from MIT in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. Outside of the lab, she enjoys dancing, cross stitch, video games, and doting on her guinea pig. David Bershadsky PhD Student Electrical and Computer Engineering Co-advised with Zak Page Siqi Shang

item.title: Publications
item.description: In all papers below, * means equal contribution to the manuscript. Members of the lab have been underlined. Notable papers have been highlighted. For the most up-to-date list of publications, please check Professor Chin’s Google Scholar profile and Youtube. If you would like a copy of any paper, please contact Professor Chin. Embedded Air Channels Transform Soft Lattices into Sensorized Grippers Annan Zhang*, Lillian Chin*, Daniel L. Tong, Daniela Rus

item.title: Research
item.description: Active Projects Blind Grasping Current robots can do impressive grasping tasks with cameras and other forms of computer vision. However, humans are able to accomplish more dexterous manipulations without any vision, such as striking a match, juggling or solving a Rubik’s cube. There is a clear need to build the tactile sensors, end effectors and algorithms to imitate non-visual human manipulation. In this project, the goal is to have a robot be able to reach inside a box, fumble around, and eventually find an object inside without the use of cameras.
